must go to those who attended,"

befitting Hopkins, and to those
faculty who were able to go. I
believe the presence of the faculty had a definite stabilizing
influence- upon behavior at the
University Prom."

Scholars, Educators
Meet Here Tonight
• "Dimensions of Education," this year's Deiches Conference, featuring a number of the nation's scholars,
writers and leading educators, will be held. tonight, tomorrow and Sunday in the Shriver Hall auditorium.
The conference is designed to explore a variety of
current educational problems and ideas and will include
two lectures, a demonstration, and two symposia.
Mrs. Agnes Meyer, author, journalist, and member
of numerous national educational committees, will deliver
the opening lecture, entitled "Science, Sociology, and
Education," tonight at 8:00 p.m. Mrs. Meyer will discuss
the general role of education in society.
The program for tomorrow provides a demonstration
of "Teaching at Different Levels" in the afternoon and
a symposium on "The Study of Learning" in the evening.
Dr. Jerrold R. Zacharias, professor of physics and

director of the Labratory for
Nuclear Research and Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, will teach
two consecutive classes on the
"Velocity of Light": first, to a
fifth-grade class from Montebello Elementary School, and
next, to a graduate seminar

In All Seriousness
What is the purpose of a graduation speaker? To
amuse?. To inspire? To goad to action? To edify?
These are secondary. There is only one real purpose,
one raison d'etre for a graduation speaker: to splatter
the name of the University on page one of all important
newspapers and to saturate national news media. Graduation is essentially a public relations exercise. It gives
newsmen grist for their mills and parents pride in their
sons and the University.
A speaker is not chosen for what he is likely to tell
the graduates about how to cope successfully with the
realities of the world. He is not even chosen because he
is likely to hand out (and what could be easier) visionary
preachings of how the graduates should reform the world.
The choice is for the name, for news-value.
May we suggest a list of people who will fulfill the
secondary purposes, as well as the primary?
To amuse: Mort Sahl.
To inspire: Billy Graham.
To goad to action: Fidel Castro.
To edify: Henry Krajewski, the Secaucus pig farmer
and saloon keeper, erstwhile candidate for the Presidency.
To fulfill the primary but not the secondary purposes,
may Nye suggest: Chief Justice Earl Warren, Henry Luce
or Roy Larson of Time, Inc., Jacob Malek of Russian
United Nations delegation, Carmine De Sapio, Soapy Williams of bankrupt Michigan, Francisco Franco of Spain,
Governor Faubus, or The Imperial Wizard of the Klu
Klux Klan.
The News-Letter will accept any other suggestions
and send them to the proper University authorities.

A Thankless Job
A thankless job will be up for grabs on April 16 and
17. On those days a new Student Cotoncil President will
be elected by the student body and the gentleman, who
has held the thankless post for the past yeal• and who has
performed his service commendably, will be retired to the
green pastures of law school. .
The CTicil this year, under the direction of Charlie
Ginsberg, has done a good job. Its history shows one
outstanding triumph—the opening of the library on Sundays; the usual menial, albeit necessary, pleas directed
at unamendable administrators designed to lower "bumps,"
remove paint, and quell library noise; and one colossal
failure—the trial of the seventeen painters. Ginsberg's
Council has tried to do more than a number of former
Councils. It has tried to present the student view in
regard to exam schedules and the adviser system to the
administration.
Steps have been taken to put into proper perspective
what we consider the primary duty of a student council-to represent the students to the administration. Too
often student organizations forget this duty and reverse
the procedure and becoming merely another avenue by
which administration opinion is presented to the students.
The man who succeeds Ginsberg will need to emphasize the forward steps this year's Council has taken and
to magnify its pursuit of fulfilling the primary duty of a
student government. The new President undoubtedly will
be'strapped by the obstructionist tactics of some Council
members, the "hear-all-but-do-little" administration, and
the disinterest of a large segment of the student body.
His job will be thankless but a good effort will be necessary
if Holikins is to be made a better place for the undergraduate.

Wine, Women, and Song! reads the caption on this picture. It is the front cover of one of
the fleshpot magazines currently for sale on Baltimore Street. If you look closely, you will see that
this dashing knight is wearing what seems to be a Hopkins blazer. The pocket emblem is clearlY
the seal of our university. This picture merely demonstrates the policy of Hopkins to educate
the "whole man." The champagne is of course one of those little extras which set the Hopkins
gentWman apart from tlie ordinary mortal.

Club Sunday, April 5, at 8

Mr. Anwar Ahmand, and the
officer in charge of political
' affairs, Mr. M. Alam will discuss the signficance of recent
events in Pakistan at the
meeting which is open to the
public.

For Crowded Classes
In a recent interview with. the

large classes. Some classes, such
as Dr. Long's Labor Economics
section, Dr. Lowe's Philosophy
class, and the English Literature
class in Shriver Hall, have been
the targets of student agitation,
either due to their size or to
the constant shifting to new
rooms large enough to. permit
everyone to sit down.

attributable to the popularity of
the courses; in other cases the

writers and leading educators, will be held. tonight, tomorrow and Sunday in the Shriver Hall auditorium.
The conference is designed to explore a variety of
current educational problems and ideas and will include
two lectures, a demonstration, and two symposia.
Mrs. Agnes Meyer, author, journalist, and member
of numerous national educational committees, will deliver

Education," tonight at 8:00 p.m. Mrs. Meyer will discuss
the general role of education in society.

of "Teaching at Different Levels" in the afternoon and
a symposium on "The Study of Learning" in the evening.

fifth-grade class from Montebello Elementary School, and

In All Seriousness
What is the purpose of a graduation speaker? To
amuse?. To inspire? To goad to action? To edify?
These are secondary. There is only one real purpose,
one raison d'etre for a graduation speaker: to splatter
the name of the University on page one of all important
newspapers and to saturate national news media. Graduation is essentially a public relations exercise. It gives
newsmen grist for their mills and parents pride in their
sons and the University.
A speaker is not chosen for what he is likely to tell
the graduates about how to cope successfully with the
realities of the world. He is not even chosen because he
is likely to hand out (and what could be easier) visionary
preachings of how the graduates should reform the world.
The choice is for the name, for news-value.
May we suggest a list of people who will fulfill the
secondary purposes, as well as the primary?
To amuse: Mort Sahl.
To inspire: Billy Graham.
To goad to action: Fidel Castro.
To edify: Henry Krajewski, the Secaucus pig farmer
and saloon keeper, erstwhile candidate for the Presidency.
To fulfill the primary but not the secondary purposes,
may Nye suggest: Chief Justice Earl Warren, Henry Luce
or Roy Larson of Time, Inc., Jacob Malek of Russian
United Nations delegation, Carmine De Sapio, Soapy Williams of bankrupt Michigan, Francisco Franco of Spain,
Governor Faubus, or The Imperial Wizard of the Klu
Klux Klan.
The News-Letter will accept any other suggestions
and send them to the proper University authorities.

A Thankless Job
A thankless job will be up for grabs on April 16 and
17. On those days a new Student Cotoncil President will
be elected by the student body and the gentleman, who
has held the thankless post for the past yeal• and who has
performed his service commendably, will be retired to the
green pastures of law school. .
The CTicil this year, under the direction of Charlie
Ginsberg, has done a good job. Its history shows one
outstanding triumph—the opening of the library on Sundays; the usual menial, albeit necessary, pleas directed
at unamendable administrators designed to lower "bumps,"
remove paint, and quell library noise; and one colossal
failure—the trial of the seventeen painters. Ginsberg's
Council has tried to do more than a number of former
Councils. It has tried to present the student view in
regard to exam schedules and the adviser system to the
administration.
Steps have been taken to put into proper perspective
what we consider the primary duty of a student council-to represent the students to the administration. Too
often student organizations forget this duty and reverse
the procedure and becoming merely another avenue by
which administration opinion is presented to the students.
The man who succeeds Ginsberg will need to emphasize the forward steps this year's Council has taken and
to magnify its pursuit of fulfilling the primary duty of a
student government. The new President undoubtedly will
be'strapped by the obstructionist tactics of some Council
members, the "hear-all-but-do-little" administration, and
the disinterest of a large segment of the student body.
His job will be thankless but a good effort will be necessary
if Holikins is to be made a better place for the undergraduate.

Wine, Women, and Song! reads the caption on this picture. It is the front cover of one of
the fleshpot magazines currently for sale on Baltimore Street. If you look closely, you will see that
this dashing knight is wearing what seems to be a Hopkins blazer. The pocket emblem is clearlY
the seal of our university. This picture merely demonstrates the policy of Hopkins to educate
the "whole man." The champagne is of course one of those little extras which set the Hopkins
gentWman apart from tlie ordinary mortal.

In a recent interview with. the
News-Letter the Registrar, Miss
Irene Davis explained the university's current problem of extra
large classes. Some classes, such
as Dr. Long's Labor Economics
section, Dr. Lowe's Philosophy
class, and the English Literature
class in Shriver Hall, have been
the targets of student agitation,
either due to their size or to
the constant shifting to new
rooms large enough to. permit
everyone to sit down.
Miss Davis pointed out this
year's second semester overpopulation in certain classes was
attributable to the popularity of
the courses; in other cases the
introductory courses were necessary for a larger number of advanced studies; and there is the

forecast second semester class
